title: Mathematics: Factors and Multiples
description: Explore factors, multiples, common factors, common multiples, prime/composite numbers, HCF, and LCM for Class 5 students through clear definitions and examples.

subtopics.title: What are Factors?
subtopics.content:
## Factors Explained

A factor of a number divides that number exactly without leaving a remainder. Factors are the numbers we multiply to get another number.

### Examples:
- Factors of 12 are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12

Factors help identify pairs that multiply to the original number.
subtopics.codeExample:
### Practice:
- List factors of 18: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18
- Find factors of 10: 1, 2, 5, 10

### Activity:
Identify factor pairs for 24.

subtopics.title: What are Multiples?
subtopics.content:
## Multiples Explained

A multiple of a number is obtained by multiplying it by whole numbers like 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

### Examples:
- Multiples of 7: 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49

Multiples show repeated addition of the number.
subtopics.codeExample:
### Practice:
- List first 5 multiples of 3: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15
- Multiples of 4: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20

### Activity:
Write multiples of 5 up to 30.

subtopics.title: Common Factors
subtopics.content:
## Common Factors

Common factors are numbers shared by two or more numbers.

### Example:
- Factors of 12: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12
- Factors of 18: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18
- Common factors: 1, 2, 3, 6
subtopics.codeExample:
### Practice:
- Common factors of 15 and 25: 1, 5
- Common factors of 20 and 30: 1, 2, 5, 10

### Activity:
Find common factors of 8 and 12.

subtopics.title: Common Multiples
subtopics.content:
## Common Multiples

Common multiples are multiples shared by two or more numbers.

### Example:
- Multiples of 3: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18
- Multiples of 4: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20
- Common multiples: 12, 24, 36
subtopics.codeExample:
### Practice:
- Common multiples of 2 and 5: 10, 20, 30
- First common multiple of 6 and 8: 24

### Activity:
List three common multiples of 9 and 12.

subtopics.title: Prime and Composite Numbers
subtopics.content:
## Prime and Composite Numbers

- Prime Number: Has only two factors â€“ 1 and itself. Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13
- Composite Number: Has more than two factors. Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12
subtopics.codeExample:
### Practice:
- Identify primes: 17 (prime), 21 (composite)
- List composites between 10-20: 12, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20

### Activity:
Classify numbers 1-20 as prime or composite.

subtopics.title: HCF and LCM
subtopics.content:
## Highest Common Factor (HCF) and Least Common Multiple (LCM)

- HCF: The greatest number that divides two or more numbers exactly. Example: HCF of 12 and 18 = 6
- LCM: The smallest common multiple of two or more numbers. Example: LCM of 4 and 6 = 12
subtopics.codeExample:
### Practice:
- HCF of 15 and 25 = 5
- LCM of 3 and 4 = 12

### Activity:
Calculate HCF of 20 and 30; LCM of 5 and 7.
